title: Cayley's theorem
summary: In group theory, Cayley's theorem, named in honour of Arthur Cayley, states that every group G is isomorphic to a subgroup of a symmetric group.[1] More specifically, G is isomorphic to a subgroup of the symmetric group Sym ‚Å° ( G ) {\displaystyle \operatorname {Sym} (G)} whose elements are the permutations of the underlying set of G.
